prompt_init: You will receive a text. Your task is to rephrase this text without modifying its meaning. Juste output your new text, nothing else.  Here is the text: One objection to the views of those who, like Mr. Gulick, believe isolation itself to be a cause of modification of species deserves attention, namely, the entire absence of change where, if this were a _vera causa_, we should expect to find it. In Ireland we have an excellent test case, for we know that it has been separated from Britain since the end of the glacial epoch, certainly many thousand years. Yet hardly one of its mammals, reptiles, or land molluscs has undergone the slightest change, even although there is certainly a distinct difference in the environment both inorganic and organic. That changes have not occurred through natural selection, is perhaps due to the less severe struggle for existence owing to the smaller number of competing species; but, if isolation itself were an efficient cause, acting continuously and c.u.mulatively, it is incredible that a decided change should not have been produced in thousands of years. That no such change has occurred in this, and many other cases of isolation, seems to prove that it is not in itself a cause of modification.

stories:
The argument against the belief that isolation leads to species modification, as held by Mr. Gulick and others, merits consideration, specifically the lack of observable changes in isolated species where we would expect such transformations to occur. An illustrative example is Ireland, which has been geographically distinct from Britain since the end of the glacial period, a significant timeframe. Notably, very few of its mammals, reptiles, or terrestrial mollusks have undergone any measurable alteration, despite apparent environmental differences inorganic and organic.

2. Although natural selection may not have been the culprit for the absence of change in these instances, the argument that isolation is ineffective in producing modifications is fortified by the lack of transformation in various isolation cases. The modest competition among species in Ireland, resulting in less severe struggle for existence, might have impeded modifications. Nonetheless, if isolation was an efficacious cause acting cumulatively over thousands of years, it isHardly conceivable that no definite modification would have ensued. The consistent absence of such changes in Ireland, as well as numerous other instances of isolation, tends to suggest that isolation per se is not a catalyst for modification.

The point raised against the belief, held by Mr. Gulick and others, that seclusion brings about species changes, warrants reflection, particularly when considering the absence of discernible alterations in secluded species where we anticipate such metamorphoses. An elucidating instance is Ireland, which has been geographically separate from Britain since the end of the glacial period, a notable duration. Strikingly, a paucity of its mammals, reptiles, or terrestrial shelled animals have experienced any detectable mutation, noteworthy disparities in their environments notwithstanding.

2. The limited competition among species in Ireland, leading to reduced strife for existence, may have inhibited modifications. Nevertheless, if seclusion served as an effective catalyst acting progressively over millennia, it is scarcely plausible that no significant transformation would have transpired. The persistent absence of such transformations in Ireland, in addition to myriad instances of seclusion, tends to imply that seclusion itself is not a trigger for modification.
